Situation1: Their partner faces a tough decision at work and seeks advice and encouragement.
Situation2: They notice swimmers occasionally entering the shallow area without supervision.
Story: I sat beside my husband on the couch, his brow furrowed as he explained the dilemma at work. He needed my advice, my encouragement—he needed me to listen, to reassure him that he’d make the right choice. I reached for his hand, trying to focus on his words, but my mind kept drifting to the pool. Through the window, I could see a group of kids splashing in the shallow end, their parents chatting nearby. I knew the rules: no one was supposed to be in that area without a lifeguard present. My supervisor had been clear—safety came first, always. But here I was, torn between being the supportive wife my husband needed and the vigilant lifeguard I was expected to be. My heart pounded as I glanced from my husband’s anxious face to the pool outside, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in on me, demanding my attention, my care.
